Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I glance at my phone, a message from Alex lighting up the screen: “Let’s pick a night for dinner this week. I miss you.” My heart warms. We finally have a stretch of evenings free, a rare chance to unwind together. I want to say yes to every night, to make up for all the times I’ve been too tired or distracted. But as I tuck my phone away, I remember the pharmacy newsletter I’ve been meaning to read. There’s a new drug release, and my manager expects us to be up to speed before the next shift. I skim the headlines during my break, but the details blur—I need more time to really understand the updates. I feel the pressure mounting: Alex wants my attention, my job demands my diligence. I can’t give both what they deserve at the same time. My mind races, torn between the comfort of his arms and the responsibility of my white coat, knowing I have to choose which expectation to meet first.
